articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Role Puts Tesla Board Under New Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Corporate governance experts say the electric-car maker’s directors may need to rein in the chief executive, with whom many have personal ties.
articles.abstract: Corporate governance experts say the electric-car maker’s directors may need to rein in the chief executive, with whom many have personal ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Elon Musk took over Twitter last month, his stewardship of the social network has been marked by turmoil, intrigue and no shortage of questions. Here’s one: How much time is he spending on his job as chief executive of Tesla, the electric-car maker?
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Isabella Simonetti

articles.headline: As Elon Musk Cuts Costs at Twitter, Some Bills Are Going Unpaid
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk and his advisers are examining all types of expenses at Twitter. Some of the social media company’s vendors have gotten stiffed.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk and his advisers are examining all types of expenses at Twitter. Some of the social media company’s vendors have gotten stiffed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Before Elon Musk bought Twitter last month, the company’s executives had racked up hundreds of thousands of dollars in travel invoices that the social media service planned to pay.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Inside Sam Bankman-Fried’s Quest to Win Friends and Influence People
articles.snippet: In just three years, the FTX co-founder built a massive operation to woo politicians, regulators and nonprofits to support his crypto goals.
articles.abstract: In just three years, the FTX co-founder built a massive operation to woo politicians, regulators and nonprofits to support his crypto goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, the founder of a Chicago nonprofit that works with recently incarcerated people got an email from the father of Sam Bankman-Fried, offering to make a donation on behalf of his son’s cryptocurrency exchange.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: In Blow to Trump, Supreme Court Permits House to Obtain His Tax Returns
articles.snippet: Ending a long legal fight, the Supreme Court rejected the former president’s request that it block the I.R.S. from turning over the files.
articles.abstract: Ending a long legal fight, the Supreme Court rejected the former president’s request that it block the I.R.S. from turning over the files.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for a House committee to obtain former President Donald J. Trump’s tax returns, refusing his request to block their release after a yearslong fight.

articles.headline: A Year After the Omicron Surge, Officials See a Reduced Covid Threat This Winter
articles.snippet: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said the administration was optimistic that “we’re not going to see a repeat of what we saw last year,” when the Omicron variant swept through the country.
articles.abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said the administration was optimistic that “we’re not going to see a repeat of what we saw last year,” when the Omicron variant swept through the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials expressed optimism on Tuesday that the nation was better prepared to weather a surge of Covid-19 infections this winter compared with a year earlier, and they renewed their pleas for Americans to get an updated booster shot ahead of the holidays.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: A Lasting Legacy of Covid: Far-Right Platforms Spreading Health Myths
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has pushed social media giants like Facebook to curb Covid misinformation. But it is thriving on fringe platforms like Gab, a hub for extremist content.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has pushed social media giants like Facebook to curb Covid misinformation. But it is thriving on fringe platforms like Gab, a hub for extremist content.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after Randy Watt died of Covid-19, his daughter Danielle sat down at her computer, searching for clues as to why the smart and thoughtful man she knew had refused to get vaccinated. She pulled up Google, typed in a screen name he had used in the past and discovered a secret that stunned her.

articles.headline: After Swift Return, Iger Faces Disney’s Long-Term Challenges
articles.snippet: Robert A. Iger had been gone from the company for less than a year, but he returns to a very different Disney.
articles.abstract: Robert A. Iger had been gone from the company for less than a year, but he returns to a very different Disney.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert A. Iger moved at light-speed on two fronts in his first 24 hours as Disney’s new-old chief executive. He sought to restore stability — getting the core executive team working together again, exuding a patriarchal sense of security in a companywide email — while also announcing organizational and operating changes designed to “honor and respect” the company’s creative engines, its movie and television studios.

articles.headline: Lawsuit Takes Aim at the Way A.I. Is Built
articles.snippet: A programmer is suing Microsoft, GitHub and OpenAI over artificial intelligence technology that generates its own computer code.
articles.abstract: A programmer is suing Microsoft, GitHub and OpenAI over artificial intelligence technology that generates its own computer code.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late June, Microsoft released a new kind of artificial intelligence technology that could generate its own computer code.

articles.headline: Shooting at Walmart in Virginia Adds to Nation’s Grim Gun Toll
articles.snippet: Six were killed, as well as the gunman, in the third recent high-profile mass shooting in the United States.
articles.abstract: Six were killed, as well as the gunman, in the third recent high-profile mass shooting in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESAPEAKE, Va. — As nighttime shoppers browsed for household items or Thanksgiving necessities, an employee of a Walmart in Chesapeake, Va., took out a pistol and, without a word, a witness said, opened fire, killing five of his co-workers and a 16-year-old boy, and wounding several others before turning the weapon on himself.
articles.byline: By Chris Cameron, Jenny Gross, Eliza Fawcett, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and J. David Goodman

articles.headline: U.S. Blocks Dominican Republic Sugar Imports, Citing Forced Labor
articles.snippet: An import ban targets sugar from Central Romana Corporation, a behemoth whose sugar is sold under the Domino brand.
articles.abstract: An import ban targets sugar from Central Romana Corporation, a behemoth whose sugar is sold under the Domino brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced Wednesday that it would block shipments of sugar from Central Romana Corporation, a Dominican Republic company that produces sugar sold in the United States under the Domino brand and that has long faced allegations of subjecting its workers to poor labor conditions.

articles.headline: In Texas’ Gobbler Country, an Overlooked Mascot Gets Its Due
articles.snippet: The country is full of bird-themed mascots. But only a proud few have embraced the turkey.
articles.abstract: The country is full of bird-themed mascots. But only a proud few have embraced the turkey.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUERO, Texas — America is awash in avian mascots, its sidelines overpopulated with flocks of Ravens and Hawks, Falcons and Cardinals, Eagles and Blue Jays. But one burly bird has been all but excluded from mascot consideration: the mighty turkey.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Callaghan O'Hare

articles.headline: Two Films Hit Theaters, but Netflix Remains Committed to Streaming
articles.snippet: The company agreed to some exclusive theatrical distribution for “Glass Onion” and “Matilda the Musical,” but it’s not clear exhibitors will get much more.
articles.abstract: The company agreed to some exclusive theatrical distribution for “Glass Onion” and “Matilda the Musical,” but it’s not clear exhibitors will get much more.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery,” the much-anticipated follow-up to the 2019 sleeper hit directed by Rian Johnson, was supposed to be the moment Netflix crossed the Rubicon.
